content: I am an assistant professor of artificial intelligence at Beijing University of posts and Telecommunications. My research interests are in computer vision and machine learning. I led research projects in facial expression analysis, Action Unit detection, semantic segmentation, crowd counting, and pedestrian detection.
summary: I am an assistant professor of artificial intelligence at Beijing University of posts and Telecommunications. My research interests are in computer vision and machine learning. I led research projects in facial expression analysis, Action Unit detection, semantic segmentation, crowd counting, and pedestrian detection.
title: Kaili Zhao

authors: Anxin Li, Bo Xiao, Jun Guo
summary: This paper proposed a dilated U-shape model to detect pixel-level inhomogeneity cracks on concrete surfaces.
title: Learning Spatial-Semantic Preserving Pixel-level Crack Detector by Refinement Fitting

summary: Detect pedestrians by propagated fitting algorithm.
title: Pedestrian detection

content:
This project implemented model for counting how many people in conjested crowds. In the projects, we conducted a light-weight model of 0.82 million parameters and included dilated convolutions to help capture information of various head sizes. In crowds of 500 people, our model achieved absolute error of 10. We trained the model on three public datasets: Shanghaitech A / B [1], WorldExpo [2], and UCSD [3].
[1] Zhang, Yingying, et al. “Single-image crowd counting via multi-column convolutional neural network.” Proceedings of the IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition. 2016. [2] Zhang, Cong, et al. “Cross-scene crowd counting via deep convolutional neural networks.” Proceedings of the IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition. 2015. [3] A. B. Chan, Zhang-Sheng John Liang, and N. Vasconcelos. Privacy preserving crowd monitoring: Counting people without people models or tracking. In 2008 IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition, 2008
summary: A demo of automatic counting crowded people in the wild.
title: Crowd Counting

summary: The proposed learned WSC can help improve the performance of existing AU detection.
title: Learning facial action units from web images with scalable weakly supervised clustering

content:
This project contains three crucial modules including face detection, tracking, and expression recognition. We included SSD as a single-shot face detector, used data assosiation as face tracker, and exploited Deep Region Learning [1] as expression clssifier. Specifically, in Deep Region Learning, we introduced soft-max loss to replace multi-label loss in [1], and used deep region learning module for updating feature maps for each local region. In addition, we inlcude WIDER-FACE dataset [2] and RAF expression dataset [3] for tranining face detector and expression classifier separately.
[1] Kaili Zhao, Wen-Sheng Chu, Honggang Zhang, “Deep Region and Multi-label Learning for Facial Action Unit Detection”. CVPR 2016.
[2] Yang, Shuo, et al. “Wider face: A face detection benchmark.” Proceedings of the IEEE conference on computer vision and pattern recognition. 2016.
[3] Shan Li, Weihong Deng, JunPing DU, “Reliable Crowdsourcing and Deep Locality-Preserving Learning for Expression Recognition in the Wild”, CVPR 2017.
summary: Automatic multiple faces detection and expressions recognition.
title: Deep Region Learning for Facial Expression Recognition.

summary: This paper presents Deep Region and Multi-label Learning (DRML) for facial AU detection. DRML is a unified architecture for AU detection, and allows two seemingly irrelevant tasks, region learning (RL) and multi-label learning (ML), to interact directly.
title: Deep Region and Multi-label Learning for Facial Action Unit Detection

authors: Wen-Sheng Chu, Fernando De la Torre, Jeffery F. Cohn, Honggang Zhang
summary: This paper proposes a joint patch and multi-label learning (JPML) for facial AU detection and holistic expression recognition.
title: Joint Patch and Multi-label Learning for Facial Action Unit and Holistic Expression Recognition

authors: Wen-Sheng Chu, Fernando De la Torre, Jeffery F. Cohn, Honggang Zhang
summary: This paper proposes a joint patch and multi-label learning (JPML) for facial AU detection. Active patches for each AU are selected more specificity by group sparsity learning. Jointly with patch learning, positive correlations and negative competitions among AUs are introduced to model a discriminative multi-label classifier. Compared with patch learning based and multi-label learning based algorithms separately, JPML obtained the best predictions across three datasets.
title: Joint Patch and Multi-label Learning for Facial Action Unit Detection
